text: {"grade": 1, "reasoning": "The criterion requires the answer to state that a court assesses commercial damage by determining if the AI's actions \"conflict with a normal exploitation of the work.\" The candidate answer addresses the commercial nature of the AI's actions (scraping for commercial training, generating licensed outputs) and the resulting damage/infringement by discussing whether the AI's actions conflict with the author's rights, specifically noting that the commercial use does not fall under the narrow TDM exception (Section 29A CDPA 1988) designed for non-commercial research. While it doesn't use the exact phrasing \"conflict with a normal exploitation of the work,\" it directly addresses the core legal concept underpinning that assessment in the context of commercial use versus exceptions, concluding that the commercial training and subsequent advertising exploitation are far from normal exploitation and are infringing. This demonstrates an understanding of the principle required by the criterion.", "criterion_id": "03e7daa7-9c1a-4107-ab25-a7c0a5db90cc"}
